title: Captain Blood: His Odyssey [Rafael Sabatini]
descriptions: "Captain Blood: His Odyssey" by Rafael Sabatini follows the journey of Dr. Peter Blood, an Irish physician with a diverse background in the military and navy. Settled in the town of Bridgwater, Peter wants no part in the rebellion against the Duke of Monmouth. However, when he tends to wounded rebels from the Battle of Sedgemoor, he is mistakenly arrested for treason. Convicted by the notorious Judge Jeffreys during the Bloody Assizes, Peter is sentenced to death by hanging. Yet, King James II commutes the sentence to transportation to the Caribbean as a slave. Purchased by Colonel Bishop in Barbados, Peter's medical skills result in him being hired out instead of working in the sugar plantations. When the town is attacked by the Spanish, Peter and a group of other slaves escape, capture a Spanish ship, and become successful pirates in the Caribbean. Eventually, after the Glorious Revolution, Peter is pardoned and appointed as the governor of Jamaica for his role in saving the colony from the French.

The story follows Dr. Peter Blood, an Irish physician with a colorful past as a soldier and sailor. Despite wanting no part in the rebellion against the Duke of Monmouth, Blood is arrested and convicted of treason during the Bloody Assizes. Instead of being executed, he is transported to the Caribbean to be sold into slavery.

In Barbados, Blood is purchased by Colonel Bishop and put to work on his sugar plantations. However, his skills as a physician soon become apparent, and he is hired out by Bishop to tend to the local population. When the town of Bridgetown is attacked by the Spanish, Blood seizes the opportunity to escape with a group of other convict-slaves. They capture a Spanish ship and embark on a life of piracy, wreaking havoc on the Spanish forces in the Caribbean.

As the years pass, Blood becomes one of the most feared and successful pirates in the region. However, with the arrival of the Glorious Revolution, he is pardoned for his crimes. As a reward for his efforts in saving Jamaica from the French, Blood is appointed as its governor.

"Captain Blood: His Odyssey" is a captivating tale of adventure, resilience, and redemption. It explores themes of justice, loyalty, and the consequences of one's choices. Sabatini's vivid descriptions and well-developed characters make this novel a thrilling and engaging read.

Title: Captain Blood: His Odyssey [Rafael Sabatini]

Description: The protagonist is the sharp-witted Dr. Peter Blood, a fictional Irish physician who had had a wide-ranging career as a soldier and sailor (including a commission as a captain under the Dutch admiral De Ruyter) before settling down to practice medicine in the town of Bridgwater in Somerset. The book opens with him attending to his geraniums while the town prepares to fight for the Duke of Monmouth. He wants no part in the rebellion, but while attending to some of the rebels wounded at the Battle of Sedgemoor, Peter is arrested. During the Bloody Assizes, he is convicted by the infamous Judge Jeffreys of treason on the grounds that "if any person be in actual rebellion against the King, and another person—who really and actually was not in rebellion—does knowingly receive, harbour, comfort, or succour him, such a person is as much a traitor as he who indeed bore arms." The sentence for treason is death by hanging, but King James II, for purely financial reasons, has the sentence for Blood and other convicted rebels commuted to transportation to the Caribbean, where they are to be sold into slavery. Upon arrival on the island of Barbados, he is bought by Colonel Bishop, initially for work in the Colonel's sugar plantations but later hired out by Bishop when Blood's skills as a physician prove superior to those of the local doctors. When a Spanish force attacks and raids the town of Bridgetown, Blood escapes with a number of other convict-slaves (including former shipmaster Jeremy Pitt, the one-eyed giant Edward Wolverstone, former gentleman Nathaniel Hagthorpe, former Royal Navy petty officer Nicholas Dyke and former Royal Navy master gunner Ned Ogle), captures the Spaniards' ship and sails away to become one of the most successful pirates/buccaneers in the Caribbean, hated and feared by the Spanish. After the Glorious Revolution, Blood is pardoned, and as a reward for saving the colony of Jamaica from the French ends up as its governor.
